verses.text: King Solomon was king over all Israel.
verses.comment: Simple, direct rendering following the Hebrew.

verses.text: These were his officials: Azariah son of Zadok was the priest;
verses.comment: The Hebrew 'kohen' means 'priest.'

verses.text: Elihoreph and Ahijah, sons of Shisha, were secretaries; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
verses.comment: 'Recorder' refers to an official historian or chronicler.

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the army; Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
verses.comment: Abithar likely retained a priestly role after being removed as chief priest.

verses.text: Azariah son of Nathan was over the district governors; Zabud son of Nathan, a priest, was the king’s advisor;
verses.comment: The Hebrew term for 'advisor' is 'friend,' meaning a close confidant.

verses.text: Ahishar was in charge of the palace; Adoniram son of Abda was over forced labor.
verses.comment: 'Forced labor' involved conscripted workers for state projects.

verses.text: Solomon had twelve district governors over all Israel, who provided food for the king and his household. Each one provided supplies for one month of the year.
verses.comment: 'District governors' are also translated as 'officers.'

verses.text: These are their names: Ben-Hur, in the hill country of Ephraim;
verses.comment: The Hebrew means 'son of Hur.'

verses.text: Ben-Deker, in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth Shemesh, and Elon Bethhanan;
verses.comment: Listing the towns within the governor's district.

verses.text: Ben-Hesed, in Arubboth; Socoh and all the land of Hepher belonged to him;
verses.comment: 'Socoh' is a town in Judah.

verses.text: Ben-Abinadab, in all the region of Dor; he had Taphath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife;
verses.comment: Taphath was given in marriage to the governor, indicating royal favor.

verses.text: Baana son of Ahilud, in Taanach, Megiddo, and all Beth Shean that is beside Zarethan below Jezreel, from Beth Shean to Abel Meholah, as far as the border of Jokmeam;
verses.comment: Geographical boundaries listed for the governor's region.

verses.text: Ben-Geber, in Ramoth Gilead; the towns of Jair son of Manasseh in Gilead were his, as well as the region of Argob in Bashan—sixty large cities with walls and bronze bars;
verses.comment: 'Bronze bars' indicate fortified cities.

verses.text: Ahinadab son of Iddo, in Mahanaim;
verses.comment: Mahaniam is east of the Jordan River.

verses.text: Ahimaaz, in Naphtali; he also took Basemath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife;
verses.comment: Marriage to king's daughter as royal recognition.

verses.text: Baana son of Hushai, in Asher and Aloth;
verses.comment: Listing tribes and towns included in his region.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah, in Issachar;
verses.comment: Issachar is one of the tribes of Israel.

verses.text: Shimei son of Ela, in Benjamin;
verses.comment: Benjamin is another tribe of Israel.

verses.text: Geber son of Uri, in the land of Gilead, which had formerly belonged to Sihon king of the Amorites and Og king of Bashan. There was only one governor in that region.
verses.comment: Noting historic rulers over Gilead.

verses.text: Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand by the sea. They ate and drank and were happy.
verses.comment: Phrase from earlier OT—'as numerous as the sand by the sea.'

verses.text: Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines, and as far as the border of Egypt. They brought tribute and served Solomon all the days of his life.
verses.comment: Tribute indicates subjection and payment.

verses.text: Solomon’s daily provisions were thirty cors of fine flour and sixty cors of meal,
verses.comment: A 'cor' is about six bushels or two hundred liters.

verses.text: ten fattened cattle, twenty pasture-fed cattle, a hundred sheep, and also deer, gazelles, roebucks, and fattened birds.
verses.comment: Listing various sources of meat.

verses.text: For he had dominion over all the region west of the Euphrates, from Tiphsah to Gaza, over all the kings west of the river. And he had peace on all sides around him.
verses.comment: Indicates Solomon's far-reaching rule and security.

verses.text: Judah and Israel lived in safety, every man under his vine and his fig tree, from Dan to Beersheba, all the days of Solomon.
verses.comment: 'Under his vine and his fig tree' is a common phrase signaling peace and prosperity.

verses.text: Solomon had forty thousand stalls for horses for his chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen.
verses.comment: Some ancient manuscripts have 'four thousand' instead of 'forty thousand.'

verses.text: The district governors supplied food for King Solomon and all who came to his table, each in his month, and they left nothing lacking.
verses.comment: District governors' duty to supply provisions is emphasized.

verses.text: They also brought barley and straw for the horses and chargers to the place where it should be, each according to his responsibilities.
verses.comment: Provision for animals is mentioned distinctly.

verses.text: God gave Solomon wisdom and very great understanding, and breadth of mind like the sand on the seashore.
verses.comment: Comparison of Solomon’s wisdom to the sand on the seashore.

verses.text: Solomon’s wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the east, and all the wisdom of Egypt.
verses.comment: The 'people of the east' refers to wise men from Mesopotamia and Arabia.

verses.text: He was wiser than all other men—than Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, Calcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol. And his fame was in all the surrounding nations.
verses.comment: Names listed were known for wisdom according to ancient tradition.

verses.text: He spoke three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered one thousand five.
verses.comment: Refers to Solomon as author of Proverbs and many songs.

verses.text: He spoke about trees, from the cedar in Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of the wall. He spoke also about animals, birds, reptiles, and fish.
verses.comment: Highlights Solomon’s broad scientific knowledge.

verses.text: People came from all nations to hear Solomon’s wisdom, sent by all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.
verses.comment: Sets the scene for visit of the Queen of Sheba in 1 Kings 10.
